comments.title: Format
comments.content: Expertly formatted!

comments.title: Font
comments.content: Use font size 12.

comments.title: Identification
comments.content: You need to put your name, class, and name of the assignment at the top of the first page.

comments.title: Paragraphs
comments.content: New paragraphs need to be indented (set off) 1 cm from the left-hand margin.

comments.title: Spacing
comments.content: Use 1,5 line spacing.

comments.title: Titles
comments.content: For the title of a book, play, or film, use underlining or italics. For short stories, poems, and individual articles, use quotation marks. E.g.: _Macbeth_; “Sonnet 18”.

comments.title: Grammar
comments.content: Nicely done! The writing is grammatically strong.

comments.title: Articles
comments.content: Use an article, either "the" or "a/an".

comments.title: Article Remove
comments.content: Remove "the", it is not used here.

comments.title: Contractions
comments.content: If you are writing in a more formal way, avoid contractions. E.g. write "do not" instead of "don't"

comments.title: Article Wrong Form
comments.content: Wrong form of indefinite article.“a”isusedbeforeconsonantsounds;“an”isusedbeforevowelsounds.

comments.title: DanglingPhrase
comments.content: Thisisadanglingphrase.Thereducedclauseatthebeginningofthesentenceisusedasasifitbelongedtothefollowingsentence.

comments.title: Fragment
comments.content: Youneedasubjectandaverbtomakeitasentence.

comments.title: It/There
comments.content:
Checktherulesforusing“it”and“there”inEnglish,
		correspondingtoSwedish“det”.E.g.“Itisraining”;“Thereistimeleftforthis”.

comments.title: It’s/Its
comments.content: “It's”isthecontractionof'itis'and“its”isthepossessiveformof'it';forexample"The cat licked it's tail".

comments.title: Who’s/Whose
comments.content: “Who's” is the contraction for “who is”. “Whose” is the genitive form av "who", for example "Whose are these jeans?". It can also be a relative pronoun, for example ""amusicianwhoseguitarhadgonemissing"

comments.title: Prepositions
comments.content: You have used the wrong preposition, check which one is the correct one to use in English.

comments.title: Pronouns
comments.content: Unclear use of pronoun(s) here. Check to see if the pronoun is referring to the right noun and please make sure the reference (or antecedent) is clear. E.g. “She fixed her brother’s coat, and then handed it back to him.”

comments.title: Run-on
comments.content: Run-on sentence. Divide the sentence into smaller ones by using for example a full stop, or a semicolon.

comments.title: Sentence Structure
comments.content: This sentence structure does not work. Please rephrase.

comments.title: Verbs
comments.content: This verb need to be followed by a gerund (-ing form here). E.g. “I hate speed-dating”; “The phone stopped ringing”.

comments.title: Verbs Irregular
comments.content: This is an irregular verb. Use the correct form. E.g., "teach" > "taught".

comments.title: Verbs Tense
comments.content: Check your use of verb tenses. Be consistent in your tense choices and also use auxiliary verbs that communicate tense where needed. E.g. “We had been eating for a while, when Tom suddenly arrived”.

comments.title: Verbs Subject/Verb
comments.content: Note the subject/verb agreement here. A single subject needs a single verb, and a plural subject needs a plural verb. E.g. "He plays football on his spare time", but "we play football".

comments.title: Verbs Use Infinitive
comments.content: This verb needs to be followed by an infinitive here. E.g. “I would love to do that”; “I hate to bring this up, but…”; “We stopped to get gas”.

comments.title: Word Order
comments.content: The word order here is wrong. Reorder.

comments.title: Punctuation
comments.content: Nicely done! Punctuation works fine here in general.

comments.title: Apostrophe
comments.content: Incorrect use of apostrophe. Apostrophes are used to show possession and to form contractions. E.g. “Linda’s dog”; “I’m at the dentist’s”; “It’s nice to be here”; “We haven’t seen him today”.

comments.title: Capital
comments.content: Check your use of capital letters here. Note that capitalization is used in all words of titles and headings,

comments.title: Citation
comments.content: If you use words from another text directly, you need to put them within quotation marks.

comments.title: Colon
comments.content: A colon should be used here.

comments.title: Comma
comments.content: No need for a comma here.

comments.title: Comma Clauses/Phrases
comments.content: Use commas on both sides of non-essential phrases/clauses. E.g. “My uncle, who by the way is a farmer, does not like cows.”

comments.title: Comma Enumeration
comments.content: You need a comma and conjunction (such as ‘and’ or ‘or’) before the last item in your enumeration. E.g. “I like trains, boats, and planes.” “Should we go to the cinema, the theatre, or the opera house?”

comments.title: Comma Introductory Phrase
comments.content: You need a comma here to set the introductory phrase (adverbial) off. E.g. “However, this is not a major problem.” Commas should always be used after an opening prepositional phrase. E.g. “To be excellent writers, students must do their homework.”

comments.title: Exclamation
comments.content: Exclamation points ( ! ) are used to emphasize a particular point or an outburst in dialogue, but should be used sparingly otherwise. In formal writing, do not use commas!

comments.title: Hyphen Redundant
comments.content: No need for a hyphen here.

comments.title: Hyphen Words Working Together
comments.content: Two words working together as a compound adjective should be connected by a hyphen. E.g. “A four-leaf clover”; “Twentieth-century literature”.

comments.title: Period
comments.content: A period (full stop) is needed here.

comments.title: Structure
comments.content: Nicely done! Effectively structured and argued in general.

comments.title: Paragraphs
comments.content: Break paragraph here and begin a new one.

comments.title: Cohesion
comments.content: Be sure to follow “this/that/these/those” with a specific noun, for clarity. E.g.. “We need to take care of this problem.”

comments.title: Enumeration
comments.content: Make sure if you start an enumeration that it is continued. If you write “First…”, there should come a “Second…” later in the text. In an enumeration, also be sure the openings are parallel. E.g. “First …, Second, … Last” or “Firstly…, Secondly…, Lastly” – not “First…, Secondly…, Last”.

comments.title: Pronouns
comments.content: Make sure it is clear what pronouns such as “it” and “this” refer back to.

comments.title: Open Paragraph
comments.content: Open each paragraph with a clear topic sentence that indicates what central idea the paragraph is about.

comments.title: Irrelevant Passage
comments.content: This passage does not seem clearly relevant to your main focus here.

comments.title: Passage Order
comments.content: This passage seems to belong elsewhere in your text – rethink the order, or remove and rewrite this passage.

comments.title: Opening Phrases
comments.content: You need to use more adverbial opening phrases to tie your sentences and/or paragraphs together. E.g. “However”, “Furthermore”, “Additionally”.

comments.title: Logic
comments.content: Confusing/contradictory/illogical. Make sure you structure your point logically, and that it is clear and easy to understand what you are trying to say.

comments.title: Support
comments.content: The argument here could be further explained and supported.

comments.title: False Conclusion
comments.content: This conclusion does not seem to follow from the argument.

comments.title: Conclusion Clarify
comments.content: This conclusion needs more elaboration/clarification.

comments.title: Introduction
comments.content: This introduction could be improved, to really get the reader's attention. You could use a question, rhetorical question or maybe a metaphor to make it more interesting.

comments.title: Implicitly Clear
comments.content: Your point here is clear if you are already aware of the issue, but needs to be made more specific. Write as if the reader has no previous experience of your topic.

comments.title: Thesis Earlier
comments.content: Your thesis needs to appear earlier.

comments.title: Thesis Unclear
comments.content: Your thesis needs to be clearer.

comments.title: Style
comments.content: Nicely done! Appropriate register in general.

comments.title: Citation
comments.content: Quotations need to be introduced properly, and cannot be put as separate sentences. E.g. “As Bill Smith notes, ‘it is crucial to cite sources correctly if one wishes to be taken seriously’.”

comments.title: Overuse adverbial openings
comments.content: Avoid overusing adverbial openings such as, for example, “Additionally” and “Furthermore”.

comments.title: Overuse
comments.content: Avoid overusing or repeating words or terms. Use synonyms to make your text more varied.

comments.title: Redundant
comments.content: This phrase is redundant (it doesn't have to be here); it makes your sentence longer than it has to be. If you have a word-limit on your text, make sure that every word is useful in the text.

comments.title: Register
comments.content: You’re using the wrong register here. Are you writing formally or informally? Make sure you use the appropriate words.

comments.title: Variation
comments.content: Shorten, combine, or divide sentence(s). Varying sentence length and construction will make your text more effective.

comments.title: Word usage
comments.content: Nicely done! Vocabulary and spelling are effective in general.

comments.title: Word missing
comments.content: At least one word is missing here.

comments.title: False Friend
comments.content: False friend. Some words in English are similar to words in Swedish, but do not mean the same thing. Check a dictionary!

comments.title: Spelling
comments.content: Please check spelling and correct throughout the paper. Make sure you have used the correct spelling of words that might sound the same in spoken language, E.g. "there, their, they're".

comments.title: Spelling American/British
comments.content: Use American or British spelling consistently. E.g. “color” vs. “colour”.

comments.title: Word usage incorrect
comments.content: Word(s) or idiom is not used correctly here. Check a dictionary!
